title: 115_hr1125
content: The Act titled "Visa Investigation and Social Media Activity Act of 2017" or "VISA Act of 2017" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to include background checks and screening requirements for visa and immigration benefits processing. The "Visa Investigation and Social Media Activity Act of 2017" mandates comprehensive security checks, including background checks and review of social media activity, for visa and immigration applications to determine national security threats or eligibility. The Act requires in-person interviews for aliens seeking benefits under the Act, with a waiver for those under 10 years old. Documents in foreign languages must be accompanied by certified English translations for visa applications. The Act mandates in-person interviews for aliens applying for benefits, with exceptions for children under 10. Additional information requested by the Secretary of Homeland Security or consular officer must be provided in full and on time for visa or admission applications to be approved. SEC. 3. FRAUD PREVENTION. The Act mandates in-person interviews for aliens applying for benefits, with exceptions for children under 10. Additional information requested by the Secretary of Homeland Security or consular officer must be provided in full and on time for visa or admission applications to be approved. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to submit a plan for using advanced analytics software to detect fraud in immigration applications and ensure national security within 180 days of the Act's enactment. Implementation of the plan must begin within 1 year. The Secretary of Homeland Security must complete a benefit fraud assessment by fiscal year 2021 for various immigration applications and petitions, including those for VAWA self-petitioners, spouses under certain visa categories, and individuals seeking visas under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit findings and recommendations on reducing fraud in immigration applications and petitions to Congress within 30 days of completing each benefit fraud assessment. SEC. 4. EXPEDITIOUS EXPANSION OF ASSIGNMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY EMPLOYEES TO DIPLOMATIC AND CONSULAR POSTS. Section 428 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to assign employees to diplomatic and consular posts for visa issuance and review of applications. Subsection (i) is removed. Additionally, expedited clearance and placement of DHS personnel is required. Expedited clearance and placement of DHS personnel at diplomatic or consular posts is required within one year of assignment. $60,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2018 and 2019 to implement this provision. SEC. 5. GAO REPORT. The Comptroller General of the United States will review and report to Congress on the security of nonimmigrant and immigrant visa application processes, including how security screening and background checks are conducted and considered by the Departments of Homeland Security and State. The Comptroller General will review security screening and background checks for visa applications and expects full cooperation in providing records and information.
